headline: Bret Baier on political fallout from Times report on Comey

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: This is a FOX News alert. Hello everyone, I'm Dana Perino and this is "The Five." We begin tonight with breaking news, The New York Times this evening reporting that President Trump suggested that then FBI Director James Comey that he drop the bureau's investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn. According to The Times, in February, Mr. Trump told Comey, quote, "I hope you can let this go," citing a memo written by Mr. Comey.  The White House says the report is, quote, "Not a truthful or accurate portrayal of the conversation between the President and Mr. Comey." But opponents of the President are saying this new information is stunning evidence of obstruction of justice. It's the second straight night we've had breaking news about the President, and joining us with more on this developing story is chief political anchor Bret Baier.  Bret, I noticed that you tweeted early on when this story broke about 15 minutes later that Comey was a known note taker writing detailed memos. This may be the tip of the very detailed iceberg and could change the dynamic on the hill. I'd like for you to talk about that and also we're going to take over questions.  My question is the post, citing anonymous sources says that Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein had seen this memo before they had written a memo that Trump said originally was the reason for the firing of Jim Comey. So, I was just wondering if you had been able to track any of that down between six and 9:00 which is not a lot of time.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, good evening, good to be with you. I think that here's what we know. And it's important, in these environments, to deal in facts. What we know to be a fact from FBI sources and sources of Department of Justice is that Comey, the former FBI director, then-FBI director at the time met with President Trump February 14th, the day after Michael Flynn was fired. After that meeting, we know that he took very detailed notes. A very detailed memo, we are told, and that he was uncomfortable. What we don't have independently of The New York Times is the quote from the memo, as they report, that President Trump says to Comey, I hope you can find a way to bring this to an end. In other words, the investigation of Michael Flynn. We also don't know what the extent of the memos, and how many memos there are, and what exactly is in them.  We do know another fact that the acting FBI Director McCabe testified on Capitol Hill that there is no known interference from the White House or anyone else in the FBI investigation, that nothing has slowed the FBI agents that are doing the investigation. Also, Rosenstein, the deputy Attorney General testified to the same thing. So, I think where we are, until we get more confirmation or actually see the memo, is really, where Senator Richard Burr is, the chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee, where he said tonight, I need to see more than just anonymous sources here.   He met with Comey the day before he was fired. He and Senator Warner from Virginia, the two chairs of the Senate Intelligence Committee, they said he didn't say anything about this. He didn't tell them one thing, and he got very detailed in what he did tell them. He says, verse says, you would think he would say something if this was truly what happened. He didn't, clearly, say much to anyone as far as we can tell.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. We know that he's been invited to testify so maybe then we'll be able to get those answers at least then. We'll take it around the table, I'll start with Jesse.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Bret, I'm going to put a little "Watters' World" spin on this story. If I went out tomorrow, I'm not going do the thing.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was a nice attempt. You've been practicing, I could tell.  If I went out tomorrow in the street and I asked 10 people who James Comey was, I'd probably maybe get three, maybe four who knew, depending on the neighborhood. This is a scandal with no video, with no audio, with no sex, with no money, with no dead bodies. It's a boring scandal. No one knows the deputy AG's name, no one can pronounce the Russian defense minister's name.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I can.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There are memos, in which memo, and who sent what memo to who, no one is emotionally invested or can even understand this story. It's a process story. Now, do we think we are losing sight of what the rest of the country thinks and feels about something like this?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Well, listen. I think that you're right in that there is a large section of the country that would like Washington to work on something else. But it is a big story. I mean, potentially, potentially, if you have the President asking the FBI director to move away from an investigation, an investigation where he is told that he's not a target but yet is investigating the Trump campaign, and ties or collusion possibilities with Russia, that is a big deal. And it's a big enough deal --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did Obama say it publicly the IRS situation wasn't that big of a deal? Or that Hillary's secret server didn't put any lives at risk or didn't jeopardize that as a security? And everybody blew that off.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Jesse, you're exactly right. Trey Gowdy tonight on Martha show mentioned that saying that Gowdy are saying, Comey did not come forward the four times he said President Obama stepped in front of an investigation, namely the Hillary Clinton email server investigation by saying, essentially, it was no big deal. You're right, and there is hypocrisy here. However, right now, in this environment, as the stories come out day by day, there are elements of truth to them. Some of them have fallen apart but some of them are describing a White House that is in a tough spot and is in a chaotic moment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Bob.

utterances.speaker: BOB BECKEL, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Jesse, the four people you interviewed probably are from Nigeria. But let me ask, let's go to some facts. The fact is that they had dinner together, the fact is that Comey does keep these memos, he's a lawyer and he gave detailed information on them. The fact is somebody in the CIA leak that out to "The Washington Post." The fact is that the White House says no, so that means either Trump or Comey is lying, right?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: That is true.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Now, if that's the case, when Jesse says, this is not a big deal, the President of the United States to be positive, obstruction of justice is clearly an impeachable offense.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: If you get to that point, I think Bob you're right. You can make that claim. I think that you're going to see many calls now for the actual memo. You've already got a letter that went out tonight from Jason Chaffetz, the House Oversight Committee Chairman to the FBI, to say, we need to see these memos. You're already hearing Bob calls for the so- called tapes that the President referenced in that tweet and the White House has not talked about since. Either the tapes themselves or transcripts, and I think you're going to see more and hear more calls for a special prosecutor or special commission and that Republicans may start getting to that spot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A long way to go from here to there. Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: All right. Good evening, Bret. So, also what about the source saying that there are copious notes? I imagine there's going to be a request, you know, for those notes but what I'm curious about is, if this was the situation that was developing at that time, you know, why didn't Director Comey say anything about it? Why are we hearing about it after he's been dismissed from his position? I mean, it's the question that I would look at as a former prosecutor to say, what is the motive here, how valid is this information, why wasn't it extemporaneous, you know, happening at the time if he thought it was problematic versus waiting in the aftermath for something like this to then get leaked out.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: I agree with you, Kimberly. That's a big question. I think the memos, as far as we can tell and from what sources are telling us were kind of contemporaneous at the time, dated and marked every time he talked about something. With the big figure like the President on big items. However, why did he step up? The New York Times reports it was a close circle at the FBI who knew, but there wasn't an obstruction that was testified too by the acting FBI Director McCabe or the Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein who wasn't there at the time but clearly had the information about the DOJ and how the investigation was going.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Just real quick, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: That is the question.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Okay though, just real quick in terms of when I would proffer evidence in front of a jury, and for something like this, if you have an electronic recording or something that can be authenticated in terms of this veracity, you know, time, date stamp, that's one thing. But if somebody is writing a note, I can write a note here and I can backdate it for last June and say, well, I made this and these a series of my notes that were contemporaneous at the time. But nevertheless you can't necessarily accept it for the truth of the matter if you can't authenticate the time that it was actually produced.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Yes. I agree with you. But I think his documents were kind of seized or locked down the day he was fired. And we'll have to get into the process of what exactly happened with those memos.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. An interesting question, you know?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It seems like I see you every day now, Bret. Trump breaks more news than Michael Moore breaks lawn chairs. According to this memo, Trump said, I hope you let him go or I hope you can let this go. When you say you hope for something it's not a command. It's not saying you better do this. It's like saying, I hope I get a bicycle for Christmas and I really hope you show up to my birthday party or I really hope that you won't make loud noises, you know, when I'm sleeping. It's a hope, it's not a command. So in my mind, and I know that this isn't yet a question, it seems like it's not a big deal which is maybe why Comey didn't think it was obstructionist, so he didn't have to comply to reporting it because he knew that he could -- that what Trump was doing was what Trump does. Everything to him is like visiting a construction site. It's not what a politician says or does. He doesn't understand the internal, how internal stuff works and when he shows up it's like, you know, I really wish we could do this for cheaper.  I wish we didn't use these kinds of lights and these bathrooms. We could have done a better job. It seems to me that this is just how Trump speaks and Comey understood that this is how Trump speaks. Therefore, he didn't feel like it was required to tell the DOJ of any attempt to obstruct justice. I think I just explain the story better than anybody on the planet.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: May be you did. May be you did. You know, Steve Helton on our panel was very similar in his thoughts about being -- all right, but you are much better. All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But he had an accent.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Basically the outsider mentality, the developer mentality, and that he hasn't been around Washington to know the speaker. However, you know, I don't think it takes away from the import of this series of stories and the White House kind of dealing with all of it at once.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was trying to take the import out of it.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: I know you were.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And export.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think it was a good try.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. All right. We're going to keep talking here but thank you so much, Bret Baier.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: We'll see you, guys.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Okay. Kimberly, though, do you remember when Comey had the whole thing in 2004 about the reauthorization of the NSA program and he goes to the bedside of Attorney General John Ashcroft and he says, I'm uncomfortable with this and there is Andy Carr, the chief of staff and the Attorney -- the White House Counsel and he actually documented those things then.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's one of the reason that all those things, and as I understand, it was like a memo to file, like a contemporary utterance so that he like, documented all of this stuff. And it could be that he has times when he talked to President Obama, too. I mean, I don't know if he'll actually say that, but is it totally inadmissible to have something like that? I thought that actually was good evidence.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: No. It absolutely isn't. And so, what you would have is an evidentiary hearing to make sure to say, it is admissible, can we authenticate it? Is this something -- and the point you bring up are good, that they would argue, to say look, this is somebody that is in the pattern or practice of authenticating --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- and making, putting forward these documents. He does these memorandums. You see that there is a serious but then it begs the question, well, if you're going to put forward these documents as it relates to President Trump, then let's see the documents about President Obama and the different times that you decided to like, you know, look the other way even though you had perhaps an idea or a feeling of obstruction of justice.  Why now is this coming forward? Who is leaking this information against the President to try to make it seem like there's something that is untoward? We don't know. That's what they have investigations for. But nevertheless, the timing of it seems rather, I don't know what you're laughing about, Bob that it seems a little bit suspect, because in the wake of Director Comey being fired by the President then all of a sudden we get this oh, yes, bad on you, you tried to obstruct justice. So, these are questions that need to be asked.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: So, they need to be asked but if you go back the Obama time again, you guys have got to move forward. You know? This is not something you keep going back too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You have to move forward from the election.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: I have not said that about the election, I've said that, accept the fact that the guy is the President of the United States, barely, but he is President of the United States. But listen, when you said, you thought --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, he was president five months ago so it actually is relevant because part of this story leads back into the presidency of Barack Obama.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: If you're, now, wait a minute, look, if you're Comey --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, it does about the election.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: -- and he did not reveal that fact about the obstruction of justice, and was a good try, Greg, but you could call it hope, you could call it dirt, you could call it anything else you want, and he said take it easy on my boy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would hope --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: That's obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I would hope --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No. But that's when you would say I would hope. That's not the same, it's just not. If you understand language it's not.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: But it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But if it was and he would believe it to be obstruction and he didn't. This is very "mean girls" by the way. This whole way that Comey is doing it, very "mean girls."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: How about how he was fired?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No. Oh my God! That's a great example. He was fired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, it was like payback.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was an aggressive act that Trump did in the open. Comey did it behind closed doors.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He did it in secret. He had a friend read the memo. That's "mean girls." But Trump actually said, you're fired, you're not even here, and it's public.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Let's just assume there was a tape.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Greg, let's assume there was a tape. Let's assume there was a tape in that discussion. That came out. And that came out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: And that means President Trump obstructed justice. I don't care how you look at it, it's gone.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maybe -- meeting on a tarmac in Arizona like -- you've been worried about it.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Oh, God!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's a good point. You made a good point though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think Comey is a little bit of a drama queen. He goes to the bedside of -- he makes this huge fight with Apple after San Bernardino. You know, he gets fired, and he starts leaking, he's always interfering with Hillary and then on the eve of the election, it's always about Comey. Have anyone noticed that?

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: What I've noticed is, every law enforcement officer, every FBI officer says, he's a terrific guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: A lot of people are pretty happy he left --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Yes. He's very professional. He's very comprehensive. Leave it alone, man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think having a friend read the memo --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Can you blame Bush for eight years?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. But the bottom-line --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You read the memo.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. But the Comey had no problem when he was assuming the role of Loretta Lynch and stepping in as judge, jury, prosecutor and saying there will be no charges against Hillary Clinton, there is insufficient evidence and adding an element of the crime that does not exist.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: But what does that have to do with Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You're saying that he's a shining example and beacon of purity --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: What does that have to do with --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- and that Donald Trump tried to obstruct justice but you don't have proof of it.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: You know the law well. That's not going to stand up in a court of law. Well, because differently the fact is that Trump can obstruct justice. That is wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I'm specifically speaking to your point in making an evaluation about his character and integrity and I'm pointing to a specific examples where he was lacking in it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And also, Bob, it might not have been illegal. It might be politically unwise or painful to go through but I think that the Democrats leap to impeach immediately after hearing anonymous sources at "The Washington Post," it's a little bit of a stretch.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: No, they should have moved to impeach now but let's clarify something. It is not a political issue. When he said lay off my boy, that is obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. We got to run. Nice more to come on "The Five". Greg got some advice on how to react to the recent news about the Trump administration. Can't wait. That's straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Every day we are told this is it for the Trump administration. It's over. Pack up the jet. Leave the keys to the White House with Pence. True, Trump makes it pretty easy for his critics. He's a lotion for commotion. What he says out loud makes leaking so easy. But now all the coverage of him is a nonstop shrieking car alarm as Trump defenders fight every battle like it's the last. But maybe everyone should calm down and -- I can't believe I'm going to say this -- listen to Nancy: HOUSE MINORITY LEADER NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF. Again, you're talking about impeachment, you're talking about what are the facts? Not that I don't like him and I don't like his hair. What are the facts? I don't like what he said about this. What are the facts that you would make a case on? What are the rules that he may have violated? If you don't have that case, you're just participating in more hearsay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. For more on this, we go to hell. Just as I thought, hell has frozen over. Nancy is right. And by admitting that I now have a rash all over my body.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Again?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But when she --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Well, what else is new?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When Nancy is the voice of reason you know things are nuts. But the point is, we need to separate the personality from the policies. When you do, you see Trump's policies are largely benign. It's his behavior that's so brash. And the hate toward him so visceral that every misstep becomes the end. So, will the American public finally grow tired of the coverage before they tire of Trump? Who knows? Because both are exhausting. So does President Trump talk out of turn? Yes. That's plausible. But then are his words exaggerated by those who can't accept an election result? Yes. That's plausible too. See, the two extremes -- is he nefarious or noble -- are never right. It's always going to be in the middle. So instead, relax. Everybody relax and take inspiration from the world's greatest movie. KEVIN BACON AS CHIP DILLER IN "ANIMAL HOUSE": Remain calm.

utterances.speaker: BACON
utterances.sentences: Remain calm! All is well!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That worked out well. Kimberly, you're related to Nancy Pelosi by one of your many marriages.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: That's so mean. That's fake news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Isn't it refreshing that she's the voice of moderation?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: The evanescence and through marriage.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: You don't need to be defensive, it's fine.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Fine, whatever.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: It's the five marriages that's the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I actually agree with her like you said. I thought she was lucid, she made sense. That's actually accurate. We can't run around with like hearsay. What are the facts versus the media hysteria? They bought in in an end outcome without even wondering, caring, or delivering about any supporting facts and that's a problem. So, they're a long way from being able to accomplish or achieve that because they have fanciful dreams like children in Toyland about impeachment and then obviously trying to take back the house. But you can't just do that without some kind of wrongdoing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Bob, I'm sure you'll going to agree with me on this but it seems like this story about Russia is already dying on the vine. It's over.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: How is your stomach, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's great.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: That's us dying on the vine. You know?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So, he said he's in better physical health than you.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Actually, I think I maybe, except for my legs. But anyway. But I'm not older. So, let me just say, you said something, did you say something?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Look at Bill.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: You little peasy ant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I bought you dinner tonight.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: I know. But you're still my son.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No more dinner, Bob.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Why did you buy him?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Chinese.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Not shrimp.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Like what Dana have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Fish?

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: Fish, it was fish and shrimp?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: There is no shrimp though.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Bob, make your point.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh my God!

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: I'm trying to, but I got interrupted as usual.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You get distracted. The facts. You keep talking about facts. I agree with Kimberly. I think you've set it up exactly right but there are some facts that we do know, that a highly classified intelligence operation was leaked. That's a fact. The reason we know that is the name of the town, and it was controlled by ISIS. So, that's -- very few people knew that. It was a highly classified operation. That leak emanated from somebody in the White House. Now, in that room, and the Oval Office that day, because the only people who would know about this intelligence operation would be the president, McMasters, and the secretaries of state and defense. That's it. So, one of them may have leaked it. Now, the other three said they weren't talking. They won't let the President talk. So, more than likely and the President sort of admitted it, too. He said, yes, it's a Russian thing -- wait a second, so that's a fact. And the fact was that an agent left there and called the CIA, and the NSA to warn them about this, that's a fact. Now, when you have those facts in front of you, what do you say? Donald Trump leaks a classified operation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't like President Obama's White House, remember the raid on Osama bin Laden? That ended up with --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.sentences: I was hoping you of all people would not go back there.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But there's a --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is a very good point. You know what else? I have a "Washington Post" headline here from last summer when Obama was president. U.S. offers to share Syria intelligence on terror. Okay? Hey, how about Bradley Manning. Now, Chelsea Manning, didn't he leak all types of classified information and President Obama gave him clemency? How about Edward Snowden?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He was a hero for the left. He leaked all of this information. The left is outraged when things are leaks. Listen. Perhaps President Obama -- President Trump said the wrong thing. And perhaps maybe things were compromised. And if he did, that's wrong. And that's a mistake. But he's trying to keep us safe. And he's trying to work with Russia to save lives. And if you say Trump shouldn't be trusted with classified information, you voted for a woman who the FBI said shouldn't be trusted with classified information.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Jesse, but this is about a laptop band that was already discussed in the press and subject of many news reports. And the statement from Tillerson, from Dina Powell, right? And from McMaster was that no direct sources, military operations, procedures, anything like that was released. But then The Washington Post put it forward in their paper.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: This is a FOX News alert. Hello everyone, I'm Dana Perino and this is "The Five." We begin tonight with breaking news, The New York Times this evening reporting that President Trump suggested that then FBI Director James Comey that he drop the bureau's investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn. According to The Times, in February, Mr. Trump told Comey, quote, "I hope you can let this go," citing a memo written by Mr. Comey. The White House says the report is, quote, "Not a truthful or accurate portrayal of the conversation between the President and Mr. Comey." But opponents of the President are saying this new information is stunning evidence of obstruction of justice. It's the second straight night we've had breaking news about the President, and joining us with more on this developing story is chief political anchor Bret Baier. Bret, I noticed that you tweeted early on when this story broke about 15 minutes later that Comey was a known note taker writing detailed memos. This may be the tip of the very detailed iceberg and could change the dynamic on the hill. I'd like for you to talk about that and also we're going to take over questions. My question is the post, citing anonymous sources says that Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein had seen this memo before they had written a memo that Trump said originally was the reason for the firing of Jim Comey. So, I was just wondering if you had been able to track any of that down between six and 9:00 which is not a lot of time.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS
utterances.utterance: Well, first of all, good evening, good to be with you. I think that here's what we know. And it's important, in these environments, to deal in facts. What we know to be a fact from FBI sources and sources of Department of Justice is that Comey, the former FBI director, then-FBI director at the time met with President Trump February 14th, the day after Michael Flynn was fired. After that meeting, we know that he took very detailed notes. A very detailed memo, we are told, and that he was uncomfortable. What we don't have independently of The New York Times is the quote from the memo, as they report, that President Trump says to Comey, I hope you can find a way to bring this to an end. In other words, the investigation of Michael Flynn. We also don't know what the extent of the memos, and how many memos there are, and what exactly is in them. We do know another fact that the acting FBI Director McCabe testified on Capitol Hill that there is no known interference from the White House or anyone else in the FBI investigation, that nothing has slowed the FBI agents that are doing the investigation. Also, Rosenstein, the deputy Attorney General testified to the same thing. So, I think where we are, until we get more confirmation or actually see the memo, is really, where Senator Richard Burr is, the chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee, where he said tonight, I need to see more than just anonymous sources here. He met with Comey the day before he was fired. He and Senator Warner from Virginia, the two chairs of the Senate Intelligence Committee, they said he didn't say anything about this. He didn't tell them one thing, and he got very detailed in what he did tell them. He says, verse says, you would think he would say something if this was truly what happened. He didn't, clearly, say much to anyone as far as we can tell.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. We know that he's been invited to testify so maybe then we'll be able to get those answers at least then. We'll take it around the table, I'll start with Jesse.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Bret, I'm going to put a little "Watters' World" spin on this story. If I went out tomorrow, I'm not going do the thing.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a nice attempt. You've been practicing, I could tell. If I went out tomorrow in the street and I asked 10 people who James Comey was, I'd probably maybe get three, maybe four who knew, depending on the neighborhood. This is a scandal with no video, with no audio, with no sex, with no money, with no dead bodies. It's a boring scandal. No one knows the deputy AG's name, no one can pronounce the Russian defense minister's name.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I can.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There are memos, in which memo, and who sent what memo to who, no one is emotionally invested or can even understand this story. It's a process story. Now, do we think we are losing sight of what the rest of the country thinks and feels about something like this?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Well, listen. I think that you're right in that there is a large section of the country that would like Washington to work on something else. But it is a big story. I mean, potentially, potentially, if you have the President asking the FBI director to move away from an investigation, an investigation where he is told that he's not a target but yet is investigating the Trump campaign, and ties or collusion possibilities with Russia, that is a big deal. And it's a big enough deal --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did Obama say it publicly the IRS situation wasn't that big of a deal? Or that Hillary's secret server didn't put any lives at risk or didn't jeopardize that as a security? And everybody blew that off.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Jesse, you're exactly right. Trey Gowdy tonight on Martha show mentioned that saying that Gowdy are saying, Comey did not come forward the four times he said President Obama stepped in front of an investigation, namely the Hillary Clinton email server investigation by saying, essentially, it was no big deal. You're right, and there is hypocrisy here. However, right now, in this environment, as the stories come out day by day, there are elements of truth to them. Some of them have fallen apart but some of them are describing a White House that is in a tough spot and is in a chaotic moment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Bob.

utterances.speaker: BOB BECKEL, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Jesse, the four people you interviewed probably are from Nigeria. But let me ask, let's go to some facts. The fact is that they had dinner together, the fact is that Comey does keep these memos, he's a lawyer and he gave detailed information on them. The fact is somebody in the CIA leak that out to "The Washington Post." The fact is that the White House says no, so that means either Trump or Comey is lying, right?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: That is true.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Now, if that's the case, when Jesse says, this is not a big deal, the President of the United States to be positive, obstruction of justice is clearly an impeachable offense.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: If you get to that point, I think Bob you're right. You can make that claim. I think that you're going to see many calls now for the actual memo. You've already got a letter that went out tonight from Jason Chaffetz, the House Oversight Committee Chairman to the FBI, to say, we need to see these memos. You're already hearing Bob calls for the so- called tapes that the President referenced in that tweet and the White House has not talked about since. Either the tapes themselves or transcripts, and I think you're going to see more and hear more calls for a special prosecutor or special commission and that Republicans may start getting to that spot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A long way to go from here to there. Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: All right. Good evening, Bret. So, also what about the source saying that there are copious notes? I imagine there's going to be a request, you know, for those notes but what I'm curious about is, if this was the situation that was developing at that time, you know, why didn't Director Comey say anything about it? Why are we hearing about it after he's been dismissed from his position? I mean, it's the question that I would look at as a former prosecutor to say, what is the motive here, how valid is this information, why wasn't it extemporaneous, you know, happening at the time if he thought it was problematic versus waiting in the aftermath for something like this to then get leaked out.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: I agree with you, Kimberly. That's a big question. I think the memos, as far as we can tell and from what sources are telling us were kind of contemporaneous at the time, dated and marked every time he talked about something. With the big figure like the President on big items. However, why did he step up? The New York Times reports it was a close circle at the FBI who knew, but there wasn't an obstruction that was testified too by the acting FBI Director McCabe or the Deputy Attorney General Rosenstein who wasn't there at the time but clearly had the information about the DOJ and how the investigation was going.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Just real quick, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: That is the question.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Okay though, just real quick in terms of when I would proffer evidence in front of a jury, and for something like this, if you have an electronic recording or something that can be authenticated in terms of this veracity, you know, time, date stamp, that's one thing. But if somebody is writing a note, I can write a note here and I can backdate it for last June and say, well, I made this and these a series of my notes that were contemporaneous at the time. But nevertheless you can't necessarily accept it for the truth of the matter if you can't authenticate the time that it was actually produced.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Yes. I agree with you. But I think his documents were kind of seized or locked down the day he was fired. And we'll have to get into the process of what exactly happened with those memos.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. An interesting question, you know?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It seems like I see you every day now, Bret. Trump breaks more news than Michael Moore breaks lawn chairs. According to this memo, Trump said, I hope you let him go or I hope you can let this go. When you say you hope for something it's not a command. It's not saying you better do this. It's like saying, I hope I get a bicycle for Christmas and I really hope you show up to my birthday party or I really hope that you won't make loud noises, you know, when I'm sleeping. It's a hope, it's not a command. So in my mind, and I know that this isn't yet a question, it seems like it's not a big deal which is maybe why Comey didn't think it was obstructionist, so he didn't have to comply to reporting it because he knew that he could -- that what Trump was doing was what Trump does. Everything to him is like visiting a construction site. It's not what a politician says or does. He doesn't understand the internal, how internal stuff works and when he shows up it's like, you know, I really wish we could do this for cheaper. I wish we didn't use these kinds of lights and these bathrooms. We could have done a better job. It seems to me that this is just how Trump speaks and Comey understood that this is how Trump speaks. Therefore, he didn't feel like it was required to tell the DOJ of any attempt to obstruct justice. I think I just explain the story better than anybody on the planet.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: May be you did. May be you did. You know, Steve Helton on our panel was very similar in his thoughts about being -- all right, but you are much better. All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But he had an accent.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Basically the outsider mentality, the developer mentality, and that he hasn't been around Washington to know the speaker. However, you know, I don't think it takes away from the import of this series of stories and the White House kind of dealing with all of it at once.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was trying to take the import out of it.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: I know you were.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And export.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think it was a good try.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you so much. All right. We're going to keep talking here but thank you so much, Bret Baier.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: We'll see you, guys.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Okay. Kimberly, though, do you remember when Comey had the whole thing in 2004 about the reauthorization of the NSA program and he goes to the bedside of Attorney General John Ashcroft and he says, I'm uncomfortable with this and there is Andy Carr, the chief of staff and the Attorney -- the White House Counsel and he actually documented those things then.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's one of the reason that all those things, and as I understand, it was like a memo to file, like a contemporary utterance so that he like, documented all of this stuff. And it could be that he has times when he talked to President Obama, too. I mean, I don't know if he'll actually say that, but is it totally inadmissible to have something like that? I thought that actually was good evidence.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No. It absolutely isn't. And so, what you would have is an evidentiary hearing to make sure to say, it is admissible, can we authenticate it? Is this something -- and the point you bring up are good, that they would argue, to say look, this is somebody that is in the pattern or practice of authenticating --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- and making, putting forward these documents. He does these memorandums. You see that there is a serious but then it begs the question, well, if you're going to put forward these documents as it relates to President Trump, then let's see the documents about President Obama and the different times that you decided to like, you know, look the other way even though you had perhaps an idea or a feeling of obstruction of justice. Why now is this coming forward? Who is leaking this information against the President to try to make it seem like there's something that is untoward? We don't know. That's what they have investigations for. But nevertheless, the timing of it seems rather, I don't know what you're laughing about, Bob that it seems a little bit suspect, because in the wake of Director Comey being fired by the President then all of a sudden we get this oh, yes, bad on you, you tried to obstruct justice. So, these are questions that need to be asked.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: So, they need to be asked but if you go back the Obama time again, you guys have got to move forward. You know? This is not something you keep going back too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You have to move forward from the election.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: I have not said that about the election, I've said that, accept the fact that the guy is the President of the United States, barely, but he is President of the United States. But listen, when you said, you thought --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, he was president five months ago so it actually is relevant because part of this story leads back into the presidency of Barack Obama.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: If you're, now, wait a minute, look, if you're Comey --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, it does about the election.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: -- and he did not reveal that fact about the obstruction of justice, and was a good try, Greg, but you could call it hope, you could call it dirt, you could call it anything else you want, and he said take it easy on my boy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would hope --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: That's obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would hope --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. But that's when you would say I would hope. That's not the same, it's just not. If you understand language it's not.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: But it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But if it was and he would believe it to be obstruction and he didn't. This is very "mean girls" by the way. This whole way that Comey is doing it, very "mean girls."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: How about how he was fired?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No. Oh my God! That's a great example. He was fired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, it was like payback.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was an aggressive act that Trump did in the open. Comey did it behind closed doors.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He did it in secret. He had a friend read the memo. That's "mean girls." But Trump actually said, you're fired, you're not even here, and it's public.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Let's just assume there was a tape.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Greg, let's assume there was a tape. Let's assume there was a tape in that discussion. That came out. And that came out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: And that means President Trump obstructed justice. I don't care how you look at it, it's gone.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe -- meeting on a tarmac in Arizona like -- you've been worried about it.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Oh, God!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a good point. You made a good point though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think Comey is a little bit of a drama queen. He goes to the bedside of -- he makes this huge fight with Apple after San Bernardino. You know, he gets fired, and he starts leaking, he's always interfering with Hillary and then on the eve of the election, it's always about Comey. Have anyone noticed that?

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: What I've noticed is, every law enforcement officer, every FBI officer says, he's a terrific guy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A lot of people are pretty happy he left --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Yes. He's very professional. He's very comprehensive. Leave it alone, man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think having a friend read the memo --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Can you blame Bush for eight years?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. But the bottom-line --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You read the memo.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. But the Comey had no problem when he was assuming the role of Loretta Lynch and stepping in as judge, jury, prosecutor and saying there will be no charges against Hillary Clinton, there is insufficient evidence and adding an element of the crime that does not exist.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: But what does that have to do with Donald Trump?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're saying that he's a shining example and beacon of purity --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: What does that have to do with --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- and that Donald Trump tried to obstruct justice but you don't have proof of it.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: You know the law well. That's not going to stand up in a court of law. Well, because differently the fact is that Trump can obstruct justice. That is wrong.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm specifically speaking to your point in making an evaluation about his character and integrity and I'm pointing to a specific examples where he was lacking in it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And also, Bob, it might not have been illegal. It might be politically unwise or painful to go through but I think that the Democrats leap to impeach immediately after hearing anonymous sources at "The Washington Post," it's a little bit of a stretch.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: No, they should have moved to impeach now but let's clarify something. It is not a political issue. When he said lay off my boy, that is obstruction of justice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. We got to run. Nice more to come on "The Five". Greg got some advice on how to react to the recent news about the Trump administration. Can't wait. That's straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Every day we are told this is it for the Trump administration. It's over. Pack up the jet. Leave the keys to the White House with Pence. True, Trump makes it pretty easy for his critics. He's a lotion for commotion. What he says out loud makes leaking so easy. But now all the coverage of him is a nonstop shrieking car alarm as Trump defenders fight every battle like it's the last. But maybe everyone should calm down and -- I can't believe I'm going to say this -- listen to Nancy: HOUSE MINORITY LEADER NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF. Again, you're talking about impeachment, you're talking about what are the facts? Not that I don't like him and I don't like his hair. What are the facts? I don't like what he said about this. What are the facts that you would make a case on? What are the rules that he may have violated? If you don't have that case, you're just participating in more hearsay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. For more on this, we go to hell. Just as I thought, hell has frozen over. Nancy is right. And by admitting that I now have a rash all over my body.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Again?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But when she --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Well, what else is new?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When Nancy is the voice of reason you know things are nuts. But the point is, we need to separate the personality from the policies. When you do, you see Trump's policies are largely benign. It's his behavior that's so brash. And the hate toward him so visceral that every misstep becomes the end. So, will the American public finally grow tired of the coverage before they tire of Trump? Who knows? Because both are exhausting. So does President Trump talk out of turn? Yes. That's plausible. But then are his words exaggerated by those who can't accept an election result? Yes. That's plausible too. See, the two extremes -- is he nefarious or noble -- are never right. It's always going to be in the middle. So instead, relax. Everybody relax and take inspiration from the world's greatest movie. KEVIN BACON AS CHIP DILLER IN "ANIMAL HOUSE": Remain calm.

utterances.speaker: BACON
utterances.utterance: Remain calm! All is well!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That worked out well. Kimberly, you're related to Nancy Pelosi by one of your many marriages.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's so mean. That's fake news.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Isn't it refreshing that she's the voice of moderation?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: The evanescence and through marriage.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: You don't need to be defensive, it's fine.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Fine, whatever.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: It's the five marriages that's the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I actually agree with her like you said. I thought she was lucid, she made sense. That's actually accurate. We can't run around with like hearsay. What are the facts versus the media hysteria? They bought in in an end outcome without even wondering, caring, or delivering about any supporting facts and that's a problem. So, they're a long way from being able to accomplish or achieve that because they have fanciful dreams like children in Toyland about impeachment and then obviously trying to take back the house. But you can't just do that without some kind of wrongdoing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Bob, I'm sure you'll going to agree with me on this but it seems like this story about Russia is already dying on the vine. It's over.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: How is your stomach, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's great.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: That's us dying on the vine. You know?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So, he said he's in better physical health than you.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Actually, I think I maybe, except for my legs. But anyway. But I'm not older. So, let me just say, you said something, did you say something?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Look at Bill.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: You little peasy ant.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I bought you dinner tonight.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: I know. But you're still my son.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No more dinner, Bob.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Okay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why did you buy him?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Chinese.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Not shrimp.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Like what Dana have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fish?

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Fish, it was fish and shrimp?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There is no shrimp though.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Bob, make your point.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh my God!

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to, but I got interrupted as usual.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You get distracted. The facts. You keep talking about facts. I agree with Kimberly. I think you've set it up exactly right but there are some facts that we do know, that a highly classified intelligence operation was leaked. That's a fact. The reason we know that is the name of the town, and it was controlled by ISIS. So, that's -- very few people knew that. It was a highly classified operation. That leak emanated from somebody in the White House. Now, in that room, and the Oval Office that day, because the only people who would know about this intelligence operation would be the president, McMasters, and the secretaries of state and defense. That's it. So, one of them may have leaked it. Now, the other three said they weren't talking. They won't let the President talk. So, more than likely and the President sort of admitted it, too. He said, yes, it's a Russian thing -- wait a second, so that's a fact. And the fact was that an agent left there and called the CIA, and the NSA to warn them about this, that's a fact. Now, when you have those facts in front of you, what do you say? Donald Trump leaks a classified operation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't like President Obama's White House, remember the raid on Osama bin Laden? That ended up with --

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: I was hoping you of all people would not go back there.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: But there's a --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is a very good point. You know what else? I have a "Washington Post" headline here from last summer when Obama was president. U.S. offers to share Syria intelligence on terror. Okay? Hey, how about Bradley Manning. Now, Chelsea Manning, didn't he leak all types of classified information and President Obama gave him clemency? How about Edward Snowden?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. Health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He was a hero for the left. He leaked all of this information. The left is outraged when things are leaks. Listen. Perhaps President Obama -- President Trump said the wrong thing. And perhaps maybe things were compromised. And if he did, that's wrong. And that's a mistake. But he's trying to keep us safe. And he's trying to work with Russia to save lives. And if you say Trump shouldn't be trusted with classified information, you voted for a woman who the FBI said shouldn't be trusted with classified information.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Jesse, but this is about a laptop band that was already discussed in the press and subject of many news reports. And the statement from Tillerson, from Dina Powell, right? And from McMaster was that no direct sources, military operations, procedures, anything like that was released. But then The Washington Post put it forward in their paper.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Yes, that was not vetted by the Intelligence Committee which is not the case. And yes, Trump did not know about sources and methods.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no. I'm going to get to Dana, please. I think that, it's not about sources and methods, it's kind of naivete of Trump. The fact that he thinks like since Russia and America doesn't like ISIS, we can talk about this and maybe he thought that way and then he said something but as far as I can tell, they are saying, what he said was --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the world of Intel is about nuance and complexity and these partnerships and it's very -- and you do have to tread carefully. Trust your Intel people. They said he didn't know. Okay. Why didn't he know? That's a problem too. Okay. Whatever. I do, if I could comment on Nancy Pelosi, I actually don't think that the Democrats don't want to impeach him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because I think that the longer he stays that they think that that is actually their ticket back to relevance.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: You know, you're right about that, by the way.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, thank you. Of course I was.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: You're right. It's about 2018, right now the guys down to 36 percent, he'll get killed in the midterm.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'll see about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Coming up.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The Washington Post just admits that it's biased against President Trump? That story is next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Washington Post news erupted into applause last night after their story broke an online readership record with its report that President Trump shared highly classified intelligence with Russia, according to a Twitter post by the paper's fact checker, Glenn Kessler. Matt Drudge, publisher of the highly influential Drudge Report took issue with the celebration, saying it finally clarifies how this has turned into nothing but a blood sport. Stop snoring, Bob.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dana, what is your assessment of The Washington Post newsroom?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, it's a business. We look at our ratings every day. We would love to break news. I don't know if we would break news that uses anonymous sources like this about an intelligence story.

utterances.speaker: BECKEL
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, we wouldn't do that, no.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, maybe we wouldn't, I don't know what we would do in that case. But they are in a highly competitive situation. They're being called fake news all the time. They feel like they got one over on and they cheered. I guess if we had a big night where we won, like we always do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, it so passe for us. During the night, we don't even notice winning.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We just win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We win so much.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm so tired of winning.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We know why they broke the record for viewership, because Hillary just kept pressing refresh over and over again because that's all she does in the woods with her laptop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It proves the point that, as much as the media pretends to find Trump so odious, they are so secretly or not so secretly overjoyed that they won because remember how it could be under Hillary, you said "Saturday Night Live" parities as a comparison, when they used to do Hillary, they refuse to be funny, they would use her character kind of in a gentle way where she was observing from up high. That's what they would have to be doing now in the media, in comedy. If Hillary was president, they wouldn't be doing their job. So thank President Trump for making your job great again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right and if they don't have Trump, they have Pence. Kimberly, a study came out and it said CNN dedicated 92 percent of their coverage to the Trump presidency and 78 percent were anti-Trump guests.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it is a very significant play here in terms of trying to do win the presidency of Donald Trump to the point where we really see that it's almost become a blood sport for them. That this is what they crave, they crave a certain outcome, and anything that can resonate with that to try to effectuate that outcome, they are going to run with. It's like a witch hunt. It doesn't matter if he does something positive, something good, job numbers or anything like that, they're going to find a way to turn it against them. That's the reality of the research, Bob.
